title: Statistical Inference and A/B Testing for First-Price Pacing Equilibria. (arXiv:2301.02276v3 [math.ST] UPDATED)
abstract: We initiate the study of statistical inference and A/B testing for first-price pacing equilibria (FPPE). The FPPE model captures the dynamics resulting from large-scale first-price auction markets where buyers use pacing-based budget management. Such markets arise in the context of internet advertising, where budgets are prevalent.  We propose a statistical framework for the FPPE model, in which a limit FPPE with a continuum of items models the long-run steady-state behavior of the auction platform, and an observable FPPE consisting of a finite number of items provides the data to estimate primitives of the limit FPPE, such as revenue, Nash social welfare (a fair metric of efficiency), and other parameters of interest. We develop central limit theorems and asymptotically valid confidence intervals. Furthermore, we establish the asymptotic local minimax optimality of our estimators. We then show that the theory can be used for conducting statistically valid A/B testing on auction platfo

Title: Statistical Inference and A/B Testing for First-Price Pacing Equilibria. (arXiv:2301.02276v3 [math.ST] UPDATED)
Abstract: We initiate the study of statistical inference and A/B testing for first-price pacing equilibria (FPPE). The FPPE model captures the dynamics resulting from large-scale first-price auction markets where buyers use pacing-based budget management. Such markets arise in the context of internet advertising, where budgets are prevalent.  We propose a statistical framework for the FPPE model, in which a limit FPPE with a continuum of items models the long-run steady-state behavior of the auction platform, and an observable FPPE consisting of a finite number of items provides the data to estimate primitives of the limit FPPE, such as revenue, Nash social welfare (a fair metric of efficiency), and other parameters of interest. We develop central limit theorems and asymptotically valid confidence intervals. Furthermore, we establish the asymptotic local minimax optimality of our estimators. We then show that the theory can be used for conducting statistically valid A/B testing on auction platfo
translated_title: 针对一等价格平衡的统计推断和A/B测试
translated_abstract: 我们开展了针对一等价格平衡（FPPE）的统计推断和A/B测试的研究。FPPE模型捕捉到了大规模一等价格拍卖市场中的动态，其中买家使用基于节奏的预算管理。这样的市场出现在互联网广告的背景下，其中预算是常见的。我们提出了一个FPPE模型的统计框架，在这个框架中，具有无限个物品的极限FPPE模型描述了拍卖平台的长期稳态行为，而由有限数量物品组成的可观察FPPE提供了估计极限FPPE的数据，例如收入、纳什社会福利（一种公平的效率指标）和其他感兴趣的参数。我们发展了中心极限定理和渐近有效的置信区间。此外，我们建立了估计器的渐近局部极小最优性。然后，我们展示了这个理论可以用于对拍卖平台进行统计上有效的A/B测试。
tldr: 该论文研究了一等价格平衡的统计推断和A/B测试，并提出了适用于拍卖平台的统计框架，以估计极限FPPE的关键参数。他们还发展了中心极限定理、置信区间和渐近局部极小最优性。这个理论可以用于对拍卖平台进行统计上有效的A/B测试。
en_tdlr: This paper investigates statistical inference and A/B testing for first-price pacing equilibria (FPPE), proposing a statistical framework to estimate key parameters of the FPPE model. The authors develop central limit theorems, confidence intervals, and establish asymptotic local minimax optimality of the estimators. The theory can be applied for statistically valid A/B testing on auction platforms.
